comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Son of Admiral Tōgō ... "Among the New York's passengers were Hyo Togo, twenty-two-year-old son of Admiral Togo. Young Togo has been studying agriculture in England and is enroute to his home. Despite the fact that he is son of Japan's naval hero, young Togo was the sickest man on board. He remained in his state room until etter weather was encountered two days ago. Captain Shiro Yamanouchi, of the Japanese navy...is accompanying young Togo to Japan."--"Liner New York Has Rough Voyage," Saratoga Springs Saratogian, 22 January 1916, p. 1: fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%2021/Saratoga%20Springs%20NY... A 1905 article that mentions Togo's son Hyo as a kid: cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19051001.2.200.40 And another: trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14717440?searchTerm=Togo

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: The sun., January 23, 1916, Page 11 (with photo) reported that, unlike his father, he had no martial leanings. He studied botany and the science of landscape gardening as practised by the Occidentals for two years in England. See also The evening world., January 22, 1916, Final Edition, Image 1, Column 4, „ADMIRAL TOGO'S SON HERE – Young Japanese Prefers the Flower Garden to the Battleship“ (His father Tōgō Heihachirō was Commander-in-Chief of the Combined Fleet of the Imperial Japanese Navy, see en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T%C5%8Dg%C5%8D_Heihachir%C5%8D)

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: His father is pictured on 18 Bain photos LOC has put in The Flickr Commons: www.flickr.com/search/?w=8623220@N02&q=togo

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content: All: Thanks for the various stories about young Togo. We will add more description to this record.
